Award.AwardTitle: UNS:Efficient CO2 Electrochemical Reduction on Transition Metal Dichalcogenide Catalysts

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
Salehi-Khojin, 1512647
Future energy sustainability and greenhouse gas mitigation would both benefit from man-made processes that mimic the photosynthetic conversion of carbon dioxide. Electrocatalysis is one such approach, but its application has been limited by high cost and unsatisfactory performance of commonly used precious metal catalysts such as silver and gold. This proposal explores the potential of inexpensive and earth-abundant materials as electocatalysts for converting carbon dioxide to energy-rich chemicals. The investigator will engage both PhD students and undergraduate minority students in this combined experimental and theoretical study aimed at benefiting society through the development of a sustainable carbon cycle.

The study will advance knowledge in the design of earth-abundant electrocatalysts by building on the investigator's previous discovery that transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) reduce carbon dioxide at low over-potential and extremely high reduction rate via different reaction driving forces than typical of precious metal catalysts. The work will explore the mechanism and kinetics of carbon dioxide reduction to synthesis gas in ionic aqueous electrolyte media using molybdenum disulfide and other TMDCs as catalysts, and by exploring synthesis techniques that promote formation of highly active edge sites both with and without inserted host atoms. Electrochemical impedance spectroscopy and density functional theory calculations will be used to gain in-depth understanding of the carbon dioxide reduction mechanism at the molecular level. To this end, the study will elucidate the key parameters that govern the chemistry of the new TMDC catalysts and enable the design of high-performance electrochemical processes for converting carbon dioxide to useful products.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Electrochemical conversion of CO2 to energy rich chemicals has potential to provide carbon-neutral alternative fuels, a closed-loop energy cycle, and non-battery technology for energy storage by converting concentrated CO2 streams from point sources using surplus electricity. The opportunity is provided by the rapidly evolving economy of electricity production from renewable sources that makes their conversion into chemical fuels more attractive. In this research, PI Salehi-Khojin discovered novel catalysts, transition metal dichalcogenide (TMDC), that convert CO2 efficiently, with more than 1000 times higher activity than the state-of-the-art catalysts such Ag and Au nanoparticles, with very low overpotentials, which will minimize losses in the energy conversion process. It was shown that CO and H2 (syngas) are the dominant products that can be converted to long-chain hydrocarbons later. The opportunity to efficiently convert CO2 to chemical fuels is highly transformational in the area of transportation fuels. Previous research on direct electrochemical conversion of CO2 to hydrocarbons has been focused on high temperature routes because of the difficulties in converting CO2 efficiently at low temperatures. With the new catalyst made from inexpensive and earth abundant materials and offering thousand times higher activity than previous catalysts, low temperature electrocatalytic processes are now viable for efficient CO2 conversion to syngas.Thus, this technology has potential to lower the conversion cost dramatically and has potential for disruptive advance in the transportation fuels. 

In the first and second years of this project PI Salehi-Khojin's group studied various transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDCs) (published in Science2016, http://science.sciencemag.org/content/353/6298/467) and their doped structures to electronically stimulate the active sites (published in ACS Nano 2017, https://pubs.acs.org/doi/abs/10.1021/acsnano.6b06392) as potential catalysts for CO2 reduction reaction inside 1-ethyl-3-methylimidazolium tetrafluoroborate (EMIM-BF4) ionic liquid. We have also developed the first generation of solar-to-hydrocarbon energy storage system using a novel artificial leaf platform that mimics the real photosynthesis process and converts CO2 to fuel using the energy only from Sun without input electricity. These studies have been covered by more than one thousand news organizations, including Times, Guardian, New York Post, Huffington Post, The Christian Science Monitor, Forbes, Daily Mail, Science Magazine, Midwest Energy News, and Chicago Tribune. 

In the thrid year of this project, we aimed to search for inexpensive but efficient electrolytes to replace EMIM-BF4 ionic liquid which is expensive for practical applications. Among various solvents, we found that choline chloride has high CO2 capture ability, and is an ideal co-catalyst for CO2 reduction. It is a common food additive for livestock and a waste product of soybean oil production, and if saturated with the  CO2 acts as a buffer solution (pH~7.6) that controls pH during the reactions. For the first time, PI Salehi-Khojin demonstrated a continuous solar-driven electrocatalysis process that effectively converts CO2 to energy rich chemical (in-print in Advanced Energy Materials, impact factor of 23). We have obtained solar-to-fuel and catalytic conversion efficiencies of 23% and 83%, respectively, for our solar-driven CO2conversion system. These are by far the highest efficiencies reported yet, and offer a strong argument for pursuing the scale-up of the technology. 

In summary, the unique features of our technology developed during this award are: (i) record-efficiency for electro-catalytic conversion of CO2to syngas, (ii) zero emissions of greenhouse gases, (iii) sustainable operation at ambient conditions, and (v) self-standing modular technology compatible with renewable energy sources (e.g. solar, etc.).
